Fig. 1 Comparison of the FT-IR (A) and DR UV–VIS spectra (B): GMA resin (a), resins 1 (with EDA units) (b) and palladium(II) polymer supported complexes 1.2 (c), 1.3 (d), 1.4 (e) and Pd(AcO)2 (f). Fig. 2 Kinetic plots obtained for the reaction between p-bromoanisole and phenylboronic acid depending on the amine units built-in the polymer catalysts: (A) the catalysts with ∼3.6wt% Pd(II) ion loadings, (B) the catalysts with the Pd(II)max ion loadings (reaction conditions: 0.5mol% Pd., 50°C, 1.08mmol PhB(OH)2, 0.9mmol p-MeOPhBr, 1.08mmol KOH, 9ml i-PrOH/H2O (1/1; V/V)). Fig. 3 The FT-IR (KBr) spectra of catalyst 1.4: (A) KOH/ArBr=2.0, (B) KOH/ArBr=1.2. Fig. 4 HR-SEM images (COMPO mode) of catalyst 1.4: before the first use (left), after the 5th run (right). Synthesis, characteristics and study of catalytic activity in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions Karol Bester Agnieszka Bukowska Wiktor Bukowski ⁎ Faculty of Chemistry, Rzeszów University of Technology, al. Powstańców W-wy 6, 35-959 Rzeszów, Poland Faculty of Chemistry, Rzeszów University of Technology al. Powstańców W-wy 6 Rzeszów 35-959 Poland ⁎ Corresponding author. Fax: +48 17 854 36 55. Graphical abstract A series of amine functionalized resins (1–7) with ethylenediamine (EDA), N,N-dimethylethylenediamine (DMEDA), N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine (DIPEDA), 2-methoxyethylamine (MEOEA), diethylenetriamine (DETA), tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TAEA), triethylenetetramine (TETA) functionalities were prepared by chemical modification of the terpolymer of glycidyl methacrylate (20mol%), styrene (77mol%) and divinylbenzene (3mol%). The resins obtained in this way were used for preparation of two series of polymer supported palladium catalysts consisting of about 3.6wt% of Pd(II) ions (N/Pd>2) and maximal possible loadings of Pd(II) ions (8.0–15.9wt% Pd, N/Pd<2). The catalysts were characterized using FT-IR, DR UV–Vis, HR-SEM and ICP-OES methods. Catalytic studies of the cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid in a medium of the i-PrOH/H2O solvent system with KOH as a base were also performed. The effect of catalyst and KOH concentrations, the nature of amine units and aryl bromides and reaction temperature was studied. The most active catalyst could be used minimum five times to perform the coupling of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid efficiently. However, the lowering of the catalyst activity was observed after each cycle. Keywords Polymer supported palladium catalysts Gel-type polymer supports Amino functionalized polymers Suzuki–Miyaura reactions 1 Introduction Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reactions of halides or pseudohalides with boroorganic compounds are one of the most effective routes of carbon–carbon bond formation. They are particularly useful as a method for the synthesis of biaryl systems [1–4]. These reactions are currently key stages of synthesis of many drugs and advanced materials [5–9]. They have huge practical significance resulted in the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2010 awarded to A. Suzuki (together with R. Heck and E. Negishi) for palladium-catalyzed cross couplings in organic synthesis [10]. The use of palladium catalysts in organic synthesis is accompanied with the risk of contamination of final products with toxic residuals. The acceptable limits of the heavy metal residuals, including Pd ones, in pharmaceuticals are set usually at the ppm level [11]. In order to reduce problems with recovering and recycling this expensive and toxic metal, the heterogeneous catalytic systems with palladium ions or particles immobilized on inorganic and organic supports are broadly explored [12–14]. The most important advantages resulted from the use of palladium heterogeneous catalytic systems compared to homogenous catalysts are simplification of catalyst recovery from reaction products and possibility of their reuse. However, the heterogeneous catalysts are usually less active and need to conduct the reactions under more severe conditions than the homogenous systems [15]. Additionally, the loss of catalytic activity in subsequent cycles is often observed [15–17]. The agglomeration of palladium particles on the surface of supports and losses of metal loadings under reaction conditions are recognized as main reasons for decreases in catalytic activity observed for the carbon–carbon coupling reactions. Both phenomena were explained clearly by Jones et al. in their work concerned with the nature of catalytic active forms of palladium in Suzuki–Miyaura and Mizoroki–Heck reactions [15]. In that work, the authors stated based on many experimental proof that the soluble Pd(0) species (Pd(0)solv) are a true catalyst of these reactions, independently whether the catalysts containing Pd(II) ions or those with immobilized Pd(0) particles are used. According to Jones et al., the catalytic systems used in Suzuki–Miyaura and Mizoroki–Heck reactions are in fact mostly precatalysts which provide the catalytic active soluble palladium(0) (Pd(0)solv) species. Therefore, the C–C couplings performed in the present of the supported palladium catalysts occur commonly according to the quasi-homogenous “release and catch” type mechanism. Catalytically active Pd(0)solv species, are generated under reaction conditions, and they are re-immobilized on supports after completing the reactions [18–21]. Hence, to prevent or limit the loss of palladium different inorganic, organic or composite materials were previously tested as supports for palladium catalysts. The use of the heterogeneous Pd catalysts in different C–C coupling reactions has been reviewed in several works [15–17,22]. Active coals, silica gels, metal oxides, clays, aluminosilicates, different organic polymers and composite materials having both porous and nonporous nature, which can include additional functional groups capable to bond metal species, are described as potential supports for palladium species. Among all polymer materials the functionalized polystyrenes were applied mostly for immobilization of Pd(II) ions or Pd(0) particles because of their high stability under Suzuki–Miyaura reaction conditions, on the one hand, and good catalytic activity of the catalysts derived from them, on the other hand. Both the systems including Pd(0) nanoparticles [23–27] and those bearing Pd(II) complexes [28–35] were studied successfully as catalysts in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions. Such systems distinguish a low level of palladium losses. They also allow performing the Suzuki–Miyaura couplings using water [23,25,26] or other environmentally friendly solvents, e.g. water–alcohol systems [30,36]. The results obtained for different polystyrene supports inspired us to explore in more detail the possibility of the use of the weakly cross-linked amine functionalized methacrylate–styrene gels as supports for palladium immobilization. These gels can be relatively easily derived from the terpolymers of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA), styrene (S) and divinylbenzene (DVB) [37]. The GMA gels after their chemical modification in the reaction with polyamines become capable to coordinate different transition metals, including palladium. The last feature was used previously for preparation of the polymer supported palladium catalysts for the hydrogenation of substituted olefins and acetylenes [38,39]. The catalysts based on the resin cross-linked with diethylene glycol dimethacrylate (DEGDMA), bearing EDA units, turned out to be efficient in the hydrogenation of 2-butyne-1,4-diol and phenylacetylene. On the other side, a similar resin with trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane units were applied successfully for preparation of the catalytic systems for Suzuki–Miyaura reactions [40,41]. Both the low cross-linked GMA gels and the resins derived from them after treating with an excess of polyamines show good swelling ability in THF, dichloromethane, toluene, DMF and some other solvents thermodynamically compatible with their styrene cores (∼70mol% styrene). In water and low molecular alcohols, thermodynamically non-compatible solvents, these gels remain in a shrunken state [42]. Because of the relatively high reactivity of epoxy groups, they can be easily modified to incorporate new functionalities, e.g. amine groups, into polymer matrices. This phenomenon can be used for limitation on the migration of palladium species from supports to reaction mixtures, for instance, by performing the Suzuki–Miyaura couplings in the thermodynamically “bad” solvents, e.g. in i-PrOH/H2O systems, and the Pd(II) ion immobilization under conditions which facilitate swelling and decrease reactivity of the amine resins, e.g. in THF. The effectiveness of such solution was shown in our previous work [43] in which the GMA gel was applied for synthesis of polymer supported Pd(II) Schiff base complexes and explored in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions. Herein, we report on the use of a series of the polyamine functionalized gels derived from the GMA resin as supports for palladium(II) ions. To prepare these supports, the resin bearing epoxy groups were treated with ethylenediamine (EDA), N,N-dimethylethylenediamine (DMEDA), N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine (DIPEDA), 2-methoxyethylamine (MEOEA), diethylenetriamine (DETA), tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TAEA), triethylenetetramine (TETA). The amine functionalized resins obtained in this way were applied for palladium immobilization to prepare a series of the metalopolymers. They were explored as catalysts in the Suzuki–Miyaura reactions of aryl bromides with phenylboronic acid under mild reaction conditions using i-PrOH/H2O as a solvent and KOH as a basic reactant. 2 Experimental All chemicals used for preparation of the polymer supported palladium(II) catalysts and in the catalytic studies were commercially available from Aldrich, Merck or Fluka and used as received, unless otherwise stated. Monomers (styrene, divinylbenzene and glycidyl methacrylate) were purified from inhibitors by extraction with an aqueous solution of 5% NaOH and 20% NaCl. 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of epoxy functionalized resin The epoxy functionalized resin, the GMA resin, consisting of 1.4mmol epoxy groups per gram) was obtained by suspension polymerization of the mixture of glycidyl methacrylate (GMA, 20mol%), styrene (S, 77mol%) and divinylbenzene (DVB, 3mol%) using the procedure described previously [42]. 2.1.2 Synthesis of amine functionalized resin Amino functionalized resins 1–7 (see Table 1 ) were obtained by chemical modification of the GMA resin (a fraction with diameters of 75–150μm) using tenfold excess of ethylenediamine, N,N-dimethylethylenediamine, N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine, 2-methoxyethylamine, diethylenetriamine, tris(2-aminoethyl)amine or triethylenetetramine, respectively. The procedure similar to described previously in [37] was applied. The yield of the modifications was assessed by determination of the nitrogen content in the products using the Kjeldahl method. Samples of the amino functionalized resins (∼20mg) were mineralized in concentrated sulphuric acid (2ml) in the presence of a Kjeldahl catalyst using a Velp Scientifica DK6 Heating Digester thermal mineralizer. They were then transferred to a Kjeldahl system to release ammonia to a solution of boric acid. The distillates were titrated with 0.01M HCl solution in the presence of a mixed indicator (a mixture of methyl red and bromocresol green). The incorporation of amine units into epoxy groups was confirmed additionally by FT-IR spectroscopy. 2.1.3 Immobilization of palladium(II) ions To obtain catalysts 1.3, 2.1–7.1 the samples of amino functionalized resins 1–7 (173mg) were placed into 10ml glass vials equipped with screw caps. The resins were swollen in 2ml of THF and then the suitable quantities of the solutions of palladium(II) acetate (17mg) in THF (6ml) were added to the swollen resins. Next, water (0.4ml) was added to the reaction mixtures. The vials were sealed, placed on a vibration shaker and agitated at room temperature for 24h. After that time the resins were filtered off using syringes equipped with Luer valves and cotton filters and rinsed several times, by turns, with small portions of THF and water to remove an excess of Pd(II) ions. The final products were dried under reduced pressure at 40°C. The similar procedures were applied for preparation of catalysts 1.4 and 2.2–7.2. Palladium(II) acetate solutions were then taken in 20mol% excess in respect to nitrogen atoms built-in resins 1–7 with amines. 2.2 Catalysts characterization 2.2.1 Determination of palladium content The content of palladium in the polymer supported catalysts was determined using a GBC ICP-OES Integra XL spectrometer (λ =340 and 458nm). Samples of the catalysts (about 5–10mg) were mineralized in conc. nitric acid (5.0ml) using a Plazmatronika Uni Claver II microwave mineralizer. 2.2.2 Spectral characteristics FT-IR spectra of the polymers were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet 8700 spectrometer and KBr pellets. Diffuse reflectance UV–Vis (DR UV–Vis) spectra of the resins were recorded using a Jasco V-670 spectrophotometer equipped with a Jasco ISN-723 UV–Vis NIR 60mm integrating sphere and BaSO4 as a standard. 2.2.3 SEM measurements Morphology of the catalysts was studied by means of a JEOL JSM-7500 F field emission scanning electron microscope equipped with a X-ray energy dispersive (EDS) system. Images were recorded in two modes using a secondary electron detector (SEI images) and a back scattered electron detector (COMPO micrographs). 2.3 Catalytic tests General procedure: Samples of phenyl boronic acid (1.1mmol, 1.2eq.) and bromoarene (0.9mmol, 1.0eq.) were placed in 10ml vials equipped with magnetic bars and Teflon screw caps. The reactants were dissolved in 4.5ml of i-PrOH. Next, KOH (1.08mmol, 1.2eq.) dissolved in water (4.5ml) was added. Finally, samples of the catalysts (0.1–1.0mol% Pd in respect to ArBr) were then added to the reaction mixtures. The vials were then sealed and placed into a parallel synthesizer equipped with a hot plate and a cooled condenser (Carousel 12 Plus Reaction Station™). The reaction mixtures were stirred at 25, 50 or 70°C. The progress of the reaction was monitored using gas chromatography. Analytical solutions were prepared by dissolving 10mg samples taken from the reaction mixtures in 0.5ml THF with n-nonane as a standard. GLC analyses were carried out using a Agilient 7890 instrument equipped with a split-splitless injector, flame ionization detector, autosampler and HP-5+ capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis of polymer supported palladium catalysts The novel palladium catalysts described in this work were prepared using a multi-steps procedure. The epoxy functionalized resin (Scheme 1 ), used as a matrix for preparation of amine functionalized supports, was prepared from the mixture of glycidyl methacrylate (20mol%), styrene (77mol%) and divinylbenzene (3mol%), according to the procedure described previously [42]. This resin was reacted with a series of polyamines in toluene, similarly as was described previously [37]. An excess of ethylenediamine (EDA), N,N-dimethylethylenediamine (DMEDA), N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine (DIPEDA), 2-methoxyethylamine (MEOEA), diethylenetriamine (DETA), tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TAEA) or triethylenetetramine (TETA) was used for preparing a series of amine functionalized resins 1–7 (Scheme 2 ). Depending on the nature of amine reactants the products with amine group loadings from ∼1.3 (4) to 4.0mmol per g (6) (Table 1). To prove the conversion of epoxy groups under the influence of the polyamines, the FTIR spectra of resins 1–7 and the GMA resin were compared. The representative spectrum for resin 1 is presented in Fig. 1, line b. As result from comparing this spectrum with the spectrum recorded for the GMA resin (Fig. 1, line a) an appearance of new broad absorption bands in the range of 3600–2100cm−1 corresponding to N–H, O–H group stretches is followed by decreases in intensity of absorption bands in the ranges of 910 and 840cm−1 corresponding to epoxy ring stretches. The similar changes were noted for all obtained products (see Fig. S1–S6 in Appendix A). Immobilization of palladium(II) ions on amine functionalized resins 1–7 was carried out using Pd(AcO)2 as a metal ion source. The sorption was performed from a solvent system capable of swelling the amine functionalized resins. Coordination of Pd(II) ions by amine groups located inside the polymers beads and not only on their surface was facilitated in this way. The mixture of THF/H2O (20/1; V/V) was applied as a reaction medium (Scheme 3 ). Palladium(II) acetate dissolves easily in this solvent system and the obtained solutions can be used without risk of metal ion precipitation. Two series of polymer supported palladium catalysts were prepared. The first consisted of about 3.6wt% of Pd(II) ions (1.3, 2.1, 3.1, 4.1, 5.1, 6.1, 7.1) and the second maximal possible loadings of Pd(II) ions (8.0–15.9wt% Pd, 1.4, 2.2, 3.2, 4.2, 5.2, 6.2, 7.2). Additionally, resin 1 bearing EDA units was used for preparing metalopolymers 1.1 and 1.2 consisting of 0.8 and 1.5wt% Pd, respectively. It was found that the sorption capacity of the resins depended on the nature of the amines immobilized on the GMA resin (see Table 1). Resins 6 and 7, both with tetraamine units built-in were capable of bounding the largest quantities of Pd(II) ions, 15.9 (6.2) and 15.9wt% Pd (7.2), respectively. The lowest sorption capacity was detected for resin 4 bearing units of MEOEA. It bonded only 8.0wt% Pd. The resins with diamine functionalities (1, 2 and 3) were characterized by nearly the same loading of palladium, 11.6 (1.4), 11.6 (2.2) and 11.3wt% (3.2), respectively. The clear dependence between the maximal sorption capacities of the resins and a number of nitrogen groups in the amine units proves their involvement in coordination of palladium(II) ions. The immobilization of palladium(II) ions by their coordination to the amine units was proved by comparing the FT-IR spectra of resins 1–7 and the metalopolymers derived from them. Fig. 1A presents the spectra of the GMA resin (line a), EDA functionalized resin 1 (line b) and palladium complexes 1.2–1.4 (lines c–e). The spectra of the rest polymer supported Pd(II) complexes are shown in Appendix. The coordination of Pd(II) ions resulted in an increase in absorption in the range characteristic of OH and NH group stretches. A new band at 3250cm−1 was come into view as well. Furthermore, other three strong bands, at 1625, 1370 and 1320cm−1, appeared in the spectra of the metalopolymers. Their intensity increased when the palladium(II) ion loadings had increased. These bands correspond to CO and CO group stretches, respectively, and prove the simultaneous immobilization of Pd(II) ions with acetate ones. For palladium(II) acetate two bands at 1616 and 1437cm−1 were observed (Fig. 1A, line f). The differences in a picture of the spectra of resin 1 and complexes 1.2–1.4 can be recognized as another proof of interactions between amine groups in polymer beads and palladium(II) ions. The metalopolymers derived from the amine functionalized resins were also studied using DR UV–Vis technique. It was found that the immobilization of Pd(II) ions resulted in changes in absorption in the visible range of the DR UV–Vis spectra (Fig. 1B, Table 1). The higher was the loading of Pd(II) ions the stronger absorption was noted in this range. The spectra of the metalopolymers with the Pdmax loadings (e.g. Fig. 1B, line e) turned out to be similar to the spectrum of Pd(CH3COO)2 (line f). Two clearly defined maxima absorption at 262 and 398nm and one weakly defined maximum at about 550nm, on the slope of the second band, were detected in these cases. For the metalopolymer with the lower loadings of palladium(II) ions one maximum absorption was observed in the spectra. It was moved gradually to the visible range when Pd loadings had been increased. Given the N/Pd molar ratios in the prepared metalopolymers, the observed blue shifts of the bands can be explained analogically as for the homogeneous Pd(II) ion complexes with ammonia or ethylenediamine molecules [44]. It was noted previously that the maxima of absorption are moved to lower wavelength depending on a number of nitrogen atoms coordinated to Pd(II) ions. Hence, the changes in the DR UV–Vis spectra of our metalopolymers seem to be an effect of different ways of palladium coordination to the amine units. The N/Pd ratios higher than 2 were detected for resins 1.4, 2.2, 3.2, 4.2, 5.2, 6.2, 7.2, which were characterized by similar palladium loadings (Table 1). It indicates that minimum two nitrogen atoms participate in coordination of palladium(II) ions. The N/Pd ratios less than 2 found for resins 1.4, 2.2, 3.2, 4.2, 5.2, 6.2, 7.2 with the Pdmax loadings (see Table 1) suggest that in these cases some of the palladium(II) ions are complexed by two N atoms and some by only one. As a result of that two absorption bands are observed in the DR UV–Vis spectra of the metalopolymers. 3.2 Catalytic activity of the polymer supported Pd catalysts Polymer supported Pd(II) complexes 1.1–7.2 derived from resins 1–7 were explored as catalysts in the Suzuki–Miyaura reactions presented in Scheme 4 . It is known that a part of phenylboronic acid molecules is consumed to generate the catalytically active Pd(0)solv species [20]. Thus, all our studies were conducted using an excess of phenylboronic (PhB(OH)2/ArBr=1.2) to maximize the conversion of aryl bromides. The mixture of i-PrOH/H2O (1/1; V/V) was applied as a reaction medium. KOH was used as a basic reactant. The results of the experiments are collected in Table 2 . The effect of the loadings of Pd(II) ions on the rate of the reaction between bromobenzene and phenyl boronic acid was studied first. The reactions were carried out at 70°C using catalysts 1.1–1.4 in amount equivalent to 1mol% Pd(II) ions. The lowest catalytic activity was found for resins 1.1 and 1.2 with 0.8 and 1.5wt% Pd loadings, respectively (Table 2, Entry 1 and 2). They converted bromobenzene in less than 1% and 4% within 20min while the quantitative conversion of this reactant was observed when resin 1.3 (3.5wt% Pd) (Entry 3) or 1.4 (11.6wt% Pd) (Entry 8) was applied as a catalyst. Therefore, resins 2–7 were used only for synthesis of the metalopolymers consisting of about 3.6wt% Pd and those with the maximally possible (under the applied conditions) loadings of palladium ions. To make possible better diversification of catalyst activity, the next experiments were performed under milder conditions. They were carried out at 50°C using of 0.5mol% concentration of the catalysts (1.3, 2.1–7.1 and 1.4, 2.2–7.2). Additionally, bromobenzene was replaced with p-bromoanisole which is a less active reactant. Both the resins with ∼3.6wt% Pd (1.3, 2.1, 3.1, 4.1, 5.1, 6.1, 7.1) and those with Pdmax (1.4, 2.2, 3.2, 4.2, 5.2, 6.2, 7.2) enabled the quantitative coupling of p-bromoanisole with phenylboronic acid within 60–300min (Table 2, Entry 4, 5 and 25–39). Sigmoidal shapes of the kinetic curves (conversion of p-MeOPhBr vs. reaction time) were observed (Fig. 2 ). The induction periods indicated that our polymer supported palladium(II) catalysts are, in fact, the precatalysts which deliver catalytically active Pd(0)solv species under reaction conditions [15]. Given the times of the conversion of p-bromoanisole in the presence of each individual catalyst (Table 2, entry 4, 5 and 25–39) one can easily note that for the metalopolymers with DMEDA, DIPEDA and MEOEA units the induction periods could be shorten from ∼50 to ∼15min when the loading of palladium ions in the beads of the catalyst had been increased. In consequence, the reaction time shortened, as well. The different phenomenon was noted for the experiments with the resins bearing EDA, DETA, TAEA and TETA units. In these cases the induction periods shortened up first to ∼5–10min for the resins with 3.6wt% Pd (Fig. 2A) and then they lengthened again to 15–20min when the resins Pd(II)max loadings had been used (Fig. 2B). Strong diversification in activity of the polymer supported palladium catalysts depending on the nature of amine units were observed for the catalysts consisting of relatively equal (3.6wt%) quantities of Pd(II) ions (Fig. 2a). The metalopolymers bearing NH2 groups (EDA, DETA, TAEA and TETA) showed clearly higher activity than those including only secondary and tertiary amine functionalities (DMEDA, DIPEDA and MEOEA). Among the first group the highest activity was noted for catalyst 5.1 bearing DETA units. Resins 1.3, 6.1, 7.1 showed similar catalytic activity although some differences observed in the initial period of the reaction can be observed. Among the rest catalysts with 3.6wt% Pd loadings, 3.1 turned out to be more active than 2.1 and 4.1. It allowed converting p-methoxyphenyl in 75% with 180min while ∼60% conversions were noted for 2.1 and 4.1. Clearly fewer differences in activity were observed for a series of the catalyst with Pdmax. Given the data presented in Fig. 2A and B one can easily conclude that this phenomenon results from lowering activity of the first group catalysts mentioned above, on the one hand, and increasing activity of the second groups, on the other hand. An increase in amount of Pd(II) ions immobilized on resin 2 resulted in so large increase in catalytic activity of 2.2 comparing to 2.1 that this catalyst turned out to be nearly so active as 5.2 although the large diversity in the activity was observed when catalysts 2.1 and 5.1 had been used. Catalyst 5.2 bearing DETA units turned out to be the most and catalyst 3.2 with DIPEDA units the less active among the catalysts with Pdmax loadings which had been studied (Fig. 2B). These findings are completely different from the results recently published by Onozawa et al. [45]. They described the use of palladium(II) amine complexes immobilized on modified silica as effective catalysts of the Suzuki–Miyaura reaction of 4-bromobenzoic acid ethyl ester with phenylboronic acid (reaction conditions: 100°C, 0.25mol% Pd, toluene/K2CO3, reaction time 3h). It has been shown that the catalysts comprising Pd(II) ions coordinated by secondary amine groups were more active than ones consisting of tertiary amine functionalities. Furthermore, Onozawa et al. found that the catalysts with monoamine units were more active than ones with diamine moieties. Comparing the content of palladium in the beads of the fresh and recovered catalysts it was found that the resins with DETA (Table 3 , Entry 9 and 10), TAEA (Entry 11 and 12) and TETA (Entry 13 and 14) functionalities lost under reaction conditions more palladium than those with the other amine units. The lowest Pd leaching was noted for the catalysts bearing DIPEDA units (Table 3, Entry 5 and 6). Furthermore, it was found that increases in activity of the catalysts could be correlated with the losses of palladium. Complex 1.4 was recognized as the most effective from all catalysts studied in this work. It enabled the quantitative conversion of p-bromoanisole within 120min losing around 3.7% of palladium. Hence, it was used in studies involving substituted bromoarenes. In the presence of 1.4 the following order of reactivity of bromoarenes in the reaction with phenylboronic acid was observed: p-CHO-PhBr>p-F-PhBr∼PhBr>p-Me-PhBr>p-MeO-PhBr>1-Br-naphthalene>p-HO-PhBr (Table 2, Entry 8 and 23–27). This finding shows that the derivatives with the electron donor substituents react clearly slower than non-substituted bromobenzene and bromoarenes bearing the electron acceptor substituents. The exchange of phenyl ring for the naphtyl substituent resulted in lengthening the time of reactions from 20 to 60min (Table 2, Entry 27). In the presence of catalyst 1.4 the bromoarenes reacted with phenylboronic acid with high conversion. Unfortunately, under the same reaction conditions (0.5mol% Pd., 50°C, KOH, i-PrOH/H2O (1/1;V/V)) this catalysts turned out to be inactive in the cross-coupling reactions of chloroarenes, even in the case of 4-nitrochlorobenzene bearing the strongly acceptor substituent. Cross-coupling products were not detected in the reaction mixtures even after 24h reaction times. The influence of temperature and catalyst concentration on the rate of the cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid was studied in the presence of catalyst 1.4 as well (Table 2, Entry 8 and 11–15). It was noted that the reaction rate decreased clearly with lowering temperature and catalyst concentration. However, the cross-coupling could be still conducted effectively at ambient temperature using 1mol% Pd or at 70°C for 10 times less catalyst concentration. Lowering temperature resulted in diminishing in Pd leaching from the catalyst beads under reaction conditions (Table 3, Entry 19–21). The effect of KOH concentration on the cross-coupling reaction of PhBr and PhB(OH)2 was also explored using catalyst 1.4. A series of experiments with KOH/PhBr ratios 0.5, 1.0, 1.2, 2.0 and 4.0 were conducted (Table 2, Entry 6–10). The highest reaction rate was found for KOH/PhBr ratio equal 1.0 (Entry 8). It was observed that the use of KOH in excess resulted in lengthening the reaction time (Entry 9, 10). PhBr did not react quantitatively when KOH/PhBr ratio 0.5 had been used (Entry 6, 7). Furthermore, it was found that depending on KOH amount used in the reaction different leaching of palladium from the catalyst beads was observed. The highest losses of palladium were noted for the ratios equal 1.0 and 1.2 and they amounted to 6.0% and 9.5%, respectively (Table 3, Entry 16 and 19). For KOH/PhBr ratio equal 0.5 the catalyst beads lost 1.7% of Pd. The least losses of palladium were found for the ratios equal 2.0 and 4.0. In these cases the catalyst beads released to the reaction mixtures about 1.0% or less of the initial Pd loadings. 3.3 Catalyst recycling The possibility of the reuse of catalyst 1.4 was also studied. The reaction of bromobenzene with phenylboronic acid was used as a model. It was conducted at 70°C using 1mol% of Pd in respect to bromobenzene. Two series of parallel experiments were performed in which the ratios of KOH/PhBr were 1.2 or 2.0 (Table 3, Entry 8, 16, 17 and 9, 18–21, respectively). It was noted that the reaction time lengthened substantially from the 3rd cycle. Furthermore, the changes in activity of the recovered catalyst depended on the KOH/PhBr ratio. The coupling was complete within 240min for the ratio equal 2.0 (Entry 19), whereas for KOH/PhBr=1.2 only 85% conversion of PhBr could be achieved after 390min (Entry 17). For KOH/PhBr ratio equal 2.0 the recycling studies were also continued in the 4th and 5th runs as well. Then, the coupling was effectively performed within 240 and 300min, respectively (Entry 20, 21). Probably, the differences in activity of the recovered catalyst observed depending on KOH/PhBr ratio can be explained partially by the irreversible release of Pd(0) species to the reaction mixtures under reaction conditions. It was found that the loading of palladium in catalyst 1.4 for KOH/PhBr ratio equal 1.2 decreased after the 3rd cycle from 11.6 to 9.8wt% (Table 3, Entry 22) and it was nearly unchangeable for KOH/PhBr ratio equal 2.0, even after the 5th cycle (Table 3, Entry 23). The beads bearing Pd(II) ions which were initially brown changed their color under reaction conditions. They became completely black just after the first use in the case of KOH/PhBr equal 1.2. However, when KOH/PhBr ratio was set to 2.0at first the beads of 1.4 became red after the 1st use and next completely black after the 3rd cycle. The changes in color of the beads resulting from occurring reduction of Pd(II) ion to Pd(0) particles correlated with the changes in intensity of absorption bands at 1625, 1370 and 1320cm−1 corresponding to acetate ions stretches in the FT-IR spectra of recovered catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The intensity of acetate bands diminished gradually for KOH/PhBr ratio equal 2.0 (Fig. 3A) and the bands were noted even in the spectrum recorded for the beads recovered after the 5th cycle. The bands disappeared nearly completely for KOH/PhBr equal 1.2 (Fig. 3B). The last finding is a proof of occurring very fast reduction of palladium ions under these reaction conditions. The HR-SEM (in COMPO) microphotographs taken for the fresh catalyst 1.4 and for the beads recovered after the 5th cycle reveal agglomerated palladium(0) particles on the surface of the recovered catalyst (Fig. 4 ). Using EDS mode analysis the average Pd content on the surface of catalyst 1.4 was assessed. The measurements were performed in seven different points of the surface both for the fresh catalyst and the beads recovered after the 3rd and 5th cycles. The results of the measurements were presented in Table 4 . It was found that Pd content within the surface layer was nearly three times higher before the reaction than the percentage of palladium determined by a ICP-OES method for the beads as a whole and amounted to ∼33wt%. It points to uneven distribution of palladium ions within beads and their concentration within the surface layer of the beads. The content of palladium within the surface layer increased gradually for the beads recovered after subsequent cycles. The last proves the migration of palladium from the inner part of the beads to the outer sphere and the redistribution of Pd(0) particles within the surface layer of the beads occur under reaction condition. As was mentioned above, Onozawa et al. [45] noted a gradual decrease in activity of the silica-immobilized palladium(II) amine complex catalysts after each next cycle of their use. The agglomeration of palladium(0) particles on the surface of the supports and Pd leaching were recognized by them as reasons for the observed phenomenon. Those results suggested that the use of the catalysts consisting of Pd(0) nanoparticles immobilized on the amine functionalized supports would give better results than Pd(II) ions. However, clear decreases in catalyst activity in the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid were also noted in other work [40] describing the use of polymer supported Pd(0) catalysts with trans-1,2-diaminocyclohexane (CHDA) units derived from the GMA resins similar to applied herein. The reaction time lengthened from 3h in the 1st run to 22h in the 3rd (reaction conditions: 80°C, 1mol% Pd, ethylene glycol/CsCO3). The same CHDA functionalized gel used without preliminary reduction of the immobilized Pd(II) ions did not lose its catalytic activity so fast as the system with Pd(0) particles [41]. Additionally, it was more active than the catalyst in the reduced form. The coupling of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid occurred initially within 2h giving the product with 93% yield. After the 4th cycle the yield of 67% has still obtained [41].In view of the previously published data on the heterogeneous catalysts bearing similar amino ligands [40,41,45,46] our catalysts can be recognized as relatively active since they enable to perform the Suzuki–Miyaura coupling under comparatively mild conditions. 4 Conclusions Methacrylate–styrene gels with ethylenediamine, N,N-dimethylethylene-diamine, N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine, 2-methoxyethylamine, diethylenetriamine, tris(2-aminoethyl)amine and triethylenetetramine functionalities were applied for palladium(II) ions immobilization. Two series of polymer supported palladium catalysts were obtained in this way, the first with Pd loadings of ∼3,6mol% (N/Pd>2) and the second with Pdmax loadings (8.0–15.9wt% Pd) and N/Pd<2). Coordination interactions of palladium(II) ions with amine moieties were proved by FT-IR and DR UV–VIS methods. It was found that the way of the interactions between the amine ligands and Pd(II) ions and the sorption ability of the resin depend on amounts of the metal ions used for immobilization and the nature of the amine units. The polymer supported palladium catalysts were studied in the Suzuki–Miyaura cross-coupling reaction between bromoarenes and phenylboronic acid in the medium of the mixed solvent system i-PrOH/H2O (1/1; V/V), using KOH as a base reagent. It was detected that catalytically active Pd(0) species are revealed from the polymer supports and redistributed within the surface layer of the catalyst beads under reaction conditions. The catalysts showed relatively high catalytic activity and enabled to perform the coupling of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid under mild reaction conditions (50°C, 0.5%mol Pd, within 60–300min). It was also noted that the catalytic activity and the stability of the polymer catalyst depend on the nature of built-in amine. The catalyst based on EDA, DETA, TAEA and TETA units bearing NH2 groups showed higher activity than those including only the secondary and tertiary amine groups. The most effective catalyst (1.4) contained EDA was tested additionally to explore different reaction conditions (temperature, catalyst loading, KOH/ArBr ratio) and the possibility of catalyst recycling. It was found that an increase in reaction temperature intensifies the leaching of palladium from the support. The dependence between KOH amount and Pd losses detected after each catalyst recycle was found. The best stability of the catalyst was obtained for the ratio of KOH/ArBr equal 2. Catalyst 1.4 could be used minimum in five reaction cycles; however, the reaction time was lengthened gradually. The reduction of Pd(II) ions and agglomeration of Pd(0) particles on the surface of the polymer support could be recognized as a main reason for this phenomenon. To advantageous features of our catalysts belong: (i) a simple preparation procedure, (ii) mechanical strength, (iii) comparably high catalytic activity enabling to perform the Suzuki–Miyaura couplings under mild reaction conditions. coredata.dc:description: A series of amine functionalized resins (1–7) with ethylenediamine (EDA), N,N-dimethylethylenediamine (DMEDA), N,N-diisopropylethylenediamine (DIPEDA), 2-methoxyethylamine (MEOEA), diethylenetriamine (DETA), tris(2-aminoethyl)amine (TAEA), triethylenetetramine (TETA) functionalities were prepared by chemical modification of the terpolymer of glycidyl methacrylate (20mol%), styrene (77mol%) and divinylbenzene (3mol%). The resins obtained in this way were used for preparation of two series of polymer supported palladium catalysts consisting of about 3.6wt% of Pd(II) ions (N/Pd>2) and maximal possible loadings of Pd(II) ions (8.0–15.9wt% Pd, N/Pd<2). The catalysts were characterized using FT-IR, DR UV–Vis, HR-SEM and ICP-OES methods. Catalytic studies of the cross-coupling reaction of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid in a medium of the i-PrOH/H2O solvent system with KOH as a base were also performed. The effect of catalyst and KOH concentrations, the nature of amine units and aryl bromides and reaction temperature was studied. The most active catalyst could be used minimum five times to perform the coupling of bromobenzene and phenylboronic acid efficiently. However, the lowering of the catalyst activity was observed after each cycle.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium catalysts supported on amine-functionalized glycidyl methacrylate gel type terpolymers. Synthesis, characteristics and study of catalytic activity in Suzuki–Miyaura reactions
